translated: Composed by Venerable Vasubandhu
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on Imperial Order
As for how many of these four purities are derivative form but not resistant form, etc., one is derivative form but not resistant form, and three are neither derivative form nor resistant form.
As for how many are difficult to see and therefore profound, etc., all are difficult to see and therefore profound, and profound and therefore difficult to see.
As for how many are wholesome but not causes of the wholesome, etc., all are wholesome and also causes of the wholesome.
As for how many are unwholesome but not causes of the unwholesome, etc., all are neither unwholesome nor causes of the unwholesome.
As for how many are indeterminate but not causes of the indeterminate, etc., all are neither indeterminate nor causes of the indeterminate.
As for how many are causes and how many are not causes, etc., all are causal conditions and also have causes.

How many are similar and immediately antecedent conditions but not similar and immediately antecedent causes? One is not similar and immediately antecedent, nor a similar and immediately antecedent cause. Three should be distinguished. That is, the purity of faith in the Buddha may be similar and immediately antecedent but not a similar and immediately antecedent cause, or it may be both similar and immediately antecedent and a similar and immediately antecedent cause, or it may be neither similar and immediately antecedent nor a similar and immediately antecedent cause.
What is similar and immediately antecedent but not a similar and immediately antecedent cause?
It refers to the purity of faith in the Buddha that is presently arising in the future.
What is both similar and immediately antecedent and a similar and immediately antecedent cause?
It refers to the purity of faith in the Buddha in the past and present.
What is neither similar and immediately antecedent nor a similar and immediately antecedent cause?
It refers to all the purity of faith in the Buddha in the future, except for that which is presently arising.
The purity of faith in the Dharma and Sangha are also like this.
How many are objects of cognition but not that which is cognized? One is an object of cognition but not that which is cognized. Three are both objects of cognition and that which is cognized.
How many are dominant conditions that are not dominant? All are dominant conditions and also have dominance.
How many are floods but not in accord with the floods? All are neither floods nor in accord with the floods.
The four fruits of the religious life refer to the fruit of stream-entry, the fruit of once-returning, the fruit of non-returning, and the fruit of arhatship.

As for these four fruits of the religious life, how many have form, etc.? All should be discriminated. That is to say, the bodily and verbal actions included in the fruits of the religious life have form, the rest are all formless.ğŸ”½How many are visible, etc.? All are invisible.
How many are resistant, etc.? All are non-resistant.
How many are contaminated, etc.? All are uncontaminated.
How many are conditioned, etc.? All should be discriminated. That is to say, the fruit of stream-entry is either conditioned or unconditioned.
What is conditioned?
It refers to the five aggregates included in the fruit of stream-entry.
What is unconditioned?ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
That is, the cessation subsumed by the fruit of stream-entry.
The same applies to the fruits of once-returning, non-returning, and arhatship.
As for how many have karmic retribution, etc., all have no karmic retribution.

As for how many are conditionally originated, etc., all should be discriminated. That is, the conditioned fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a are conditionally originated, originated from causes, and are included in the world. If the unconditioned fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a are not conditionally originated, not originated from causes, and are not included in the world.

As for how many are categorized as form, etc., all should be discriminated. That is, the bodily and verbal karma subsumed by the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a are categorized as form. The rest are all categorized as name.

As for how many are categorized as internal bases, etc., all should be discriminated. That is, the mind, thought, and consciousness subsumed by the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a are categorized as internal bases. The rest are all categorized as external bases.

As for how many are known by the perfect knowledge of elimination, etc., all are known by the perfect knowledge of elimination.ğŸ”½As for how many are known by the perfect knowledge of elimination, etc., all are not known by the perfect knowledge of elimination.
As for how many should be eliminated and so forth, all [of the fruits] should not be eliminated.

As for how many should be cultivated and so forth, all [of the fruits] should be distinguished. That is to say, conditioned fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a are to be cultivated, while unconditioned fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a are not to be cultivated.
As for how many are defiled and so forth, all [of the fruits] are undefiled.

As for how many are results but not possess results and so forth, all [of the fruits] should be distinguished. That is to say, conditioned fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a are results and also possess results, while unconditioned fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a are results but do not possess results.
As for how many are appropriated and so forth, all [of the fruits] are not appropriated.

As for how many are derived from the primary elements and so forth, all [of the fruits] should be distinguished. That is to say, bodily and verbal actions included in the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a are derived from the primary elements, while the rest are not derived from the primary elements.

As for how many are superior and so forth, all [of the fruits] should be distinguished. That is to say, conditioned fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a are superior, while unconditioned fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a are not superior.
As for how many are existent and so forth, all [of the fruits] are not existent.

As for how many are associated with causes, etc., all should be discriminated. That is, the bodily and verbal actions and the factors not directly associated with the mind included in the fruits of asceticism are not associated with causes, while the rest are all associated with causes.

As for the relationship between these four fruits of asceticism and the six wholesome bases, a part of the six wholesome bases is included in the four fruits of asceticism, and the four fruits of asceticism also include a part of the six wholesome bases.
As for the relationship with the five unwholesome bases, they do not mutually include each other.
As for the relationship with the seven indeterminate bases, they do not mutually include each other.
As for the relationship with the three bases of defilement, they do not mutually include each other.
As for the relationship with the five bases with defilement, they do not mutually include each other.

As for the relationship with the eight bases without defilement, a part of the six bases without defilement is included in the four fruits of asceticism, and the four fruits of asceticism also include a part of the six bases without defilement.

As for how many are past, etc., all should be distinguished. That is, conditioned fruits of asceticism are either past, future, or present, but unconditioned fruits of asceticism are neither past, future, nor present.
As for how many are wholesome, etc., all are wholesome.
As for how many are bound to the desire realm, etc., all are unbound.
As for how many are the learner's path, etc., all should be distinguished. That is, the fruit of stream-entry is either the learner's path or neither the learner's nor the adept's path.
What is the learner's path?
It refers to the conditioned fruit of stream-entry.
What is neither the learner's nor the adept's path?
It refers to the unconditioned fruit of stream-entry.
The same applies to the fruit of once-returning and the fruit of non-returning.
The fruit of arhatship is either the adept's path or neither the learner's nor the adept's path.
What is the adept's path?
It refers to the conditioned fruit of arhatship.
What is neither the learner's nor the adept's path?
It refers to the unconditioned fruit of arhatship.
As for how many of these four fruits of asceticism are eliminated by seeing and so on, all are not eliminated.

As for how many are not mind and so on, all should be distinguished. That is to say, the bodily and verbal actions, and the factors not directly associated with mind included in the fruits of asceticism are neither mind nor mental factors nor directly related to mind;
if the aggregate of feeling, the aggregate of perception, and the aggregate of karmic formations associated with mind, they are mental factors and are directly related to mind;
if mind, thought, and consciousness, they are only mind.

As for how many evolve along with the mind but are not associated with feeling and so on, all should be distinguished. That is to say, the fruit of the stage of the once-returner has four alternatives.ğŸ”½Either evolving along with the mind but not associated with feeling, referring to bodily and verbal actions and the formations not directly associated with mind that evolve along with the mind and are included in the fruit of the stage of the once-returner, or associated with feeling but not evolving along with the mind, referring to the mind, thought, and consciousness included in the fruit of the stage of the once-returner.

Either evolving along with the mind and also associated with feeling, referring to the aggregate of perception and the aggregate of karmic formations associated with mind included in the fruit of the stage of the once-returner.

Or, it is neither concomitant with mind nor associated with feeling. This refers to all the formations dissociated from mind included in the fruit of stream-entry, with the exception of those that are concomitant with mind, and also cessation obtained through contemplation.
The same applies to the fruits of the once-returner, non-returner, and arhat.
As for how many are concomitant with mind but not with thought or ideation, etc., all should be discriminated. Except for their intrinsic natures, they should be understood as in the case of feeling.
As for how many are concomitant with thought but not with discernment, etc., all should be discriminated. The fruit of stream-entry is subject to four alternatives.

Or, it is concomitant with thought but not with discernment. This refers to bodily and verbal actions included in the fruit of stream-entry, and also the formations dissociated from mind that are concomitant with thought, as well as discernment.
Or, it is concomitant with discernment but not with thought. This refers to the thought included in the fruit of stream-entry.
Or, it is concomitant with both thought and discernment. This refers to the thought and thought-concomitants included in the fruit of stream-entry that are associated with thought and discernment.

Or it is neither concomitant with applied thought nor associated with sustained thought, namely, except for the dissociated factors that are concomitant with applied thought and included in the fruit of stream-entry, the other dissociated factors included in the fruit of stream-entry and cessation through deliberation.
The same applies to the fruit of the once-returner.

The fruit of the non-returner has four alternatives.ğŸ”½Or it is concomitant with applied thought but not associated with sustained thought, namely, the bodily and verbal actions concomitant with applied thought included in the fruit of the non-returner, the dissociated factors concomitant with applied thought, and sustained thought associated with applied thought.ğŸ”½Or it is associated with sustained thought but not concomitant with applied thought, namely, the applied thought included in the fruit of the non-returner, and the mind and mental factors associated with sustained thought but not associated with applied thought.

Or it is concomitant with applied thought and also associated with sustained thought, namely, the mind and mental factors associated with both applied thought and sustained thought included in the fruit of the non-returner.

Or, it is neither associated with applied thought nor with sustained thought, namely, excluding the bodily and verbal actions and formations not associated with the mind that are included in the fruit of non-returning, and the bodily and verbal actions and formations not associated with the mind that are included in the fruit of non-returning, and the sustained thought not associated with applied thought that is included in the fruit of non-returning, and the mind and mental factors that are neither with applied thought nor with sustained thought, and cessation obtained through deliberation.
The same applies to the fruit of arhatship.

As for how many are views and not objects of views, etc., all should be distinguished. That is, the wisdom included in the fruit of stream-entry is a view and not an object of views, the rest are neither views nor objects of views.
The same applies to the fruits of the once-returner and non-returner.

The wisdom included in the fruit of arhatship that is not included in the knowledge of elimination and non-arising is a view and not an object of views, the rest are neither views nor objects of views.
As for how many have the view of self as a cause but not the view of self as a cause, etc., all do not have the view of self as a cause nor are they a cause of the view of self.

How many are karma and how many are not karmic retributioá¹‡? All should be discriminated. That is, the bodily and verbal karma and volition included in the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a are karma and not karmic retribution. The rest are neither karma nor karmic retribution.
How many are karma and how many are not concomitant with karma? All should be discriminated.
That is, the fruit of the stream-enterer has four alternatives.
Either it is karma but not concomitant with karma, referring to volition included in the fruit of the stream-enterer.

Either it is concomitant with karma but not karma, referring to the aggregates of feeling, perception, and consciousness included in the fruit of the stream-enterer, and the formations dissociated from thought concomitant with karma not included in volition.
Either it is both karma and concomitant with karma, referring to the bodily and verbal karma included in the fruit of the stream-enterer.

Either it is neither karma nor concomitant with karma, referring to the dissociated formations included in the fruit of the stream-enterer other than those concomitant with karma, and the cessation obtained through deliberation included in the fruit of the stream-enterer.
The fruits of the once-returner, non-returner, and arhat are also like this.

How many are derivative form but not visible form, etc.? All should be discriminated. That is, the bodily and verbal actions included in the fruits of asceticism are derivative form but not visible form. The rest are neither derivative form nor visible form.

How many are derivative form but not resistant, etc.? All should be discriminated. That is, the bodily and verbal actions included in the fruits of asceticism are derivative form but not resistant. The rest are neither derivative form nor resistant.
How many are difficult to see because they are profound, etc.? All are difficult to see because they are profound, and profound because they are difficult to see.

How many are wholesome but not causes of the wholesome, etc.? All should be discriminated. That is, the conditioned fruits of asceticism are wholesome and also causes of the wholesome. If the unconditioned fruits of asceticism are wholesome, they are not causes of the wholesome.
How many are unwholesome but not causes of the unwholesome, etc.? All are neither unwholesome nor causes of the unwholesome.

original: å¹¾ç„¡è¨˜éç„¡è¨˜ç‚ºå› ç­‰è€…ï¼Œä¸€åˆ‡éç„¡è¨˜éç„¡è¨˜ç‚ºå› ã€‚ğŸ”½å¹¾å› ç·£éæœ‰å› ç­‰è€…ï¼Œä¸€åˆ‡æ‡‰åˆ†åˆ¥ï¼Œè‹¥æœ‰ç‚ºæ²™é–€æœæ˜¯å› ç·£äº¦æœ‰å› ï¼Œè‹¥ç„¡ç‚ºæ²™é–€æœéå› ç·£éæœ‰å› ã€‚

translated: How many are indeterminate and not causes of indeterminate dharmas? All are not indeterminate and not causes of indeterminate dharmas.ğŸ”½How many are causal conditions but not causes? All should be discriminated. If the conditioned fruits of asceticism are causal conditions, they are also causes. If the unconditioned fruits of asceticism are not causal conditions, they are not causes.

How many are similar and immediately antecedent conditions but not similar and immediately antecedent causes? All should be discriminated. That is to say, the fruits of asceticism may be similar and immediately antecedent but not similar and immediately antecedent causes, or they may be similar and immediately antecedent and also similar and immediately antecedent causes, or they may not be similar and immediately antecedent and not similar and immediately antecedent causes.ğŸ”½That which is similar and immediately antecedent but not a similar and immediately antecedent condition refers to the mind and mental factors included in the fruits of asceticism that are presently arising in the future.

That which is similar and immediately antecedent and also a similar and immediately antecedent condition refers to the mind and mental factors included in the fruits of asceticism in the past and present.

As for those that are neither similar and immediately antecedent conditions nor similar and immediately antecedent conditions, it means excluding the mind and mental factors included in the fruits of asceticism that are presently arising in the future, and the remaining mind and mental factors included in the fruits of asceticism in the future, as well as bodily and verbal actions, factors not directly associated with mind, and cessation through discernment.

As for how many are objects of cognition but not that which is cognized, etc., all should be distinguished. That is to say, the bodily and verbal actions included in the fruits of asceticism, the factors not directly associated with mind, and cessation through discernment are objects of cognition but not that which is cognized. The rest are both objects of cognition and that which is cognized.

As for how many are dominant conditions but not that which is dominant, etc., all should be distinguished. That is to say, the conditioned fruits of asceticism are dominant conditions and also that which is dominant. If the unconditioned fruits of asceticism are dominant conditions, they are not that which is dominant.
As for how many are floods but not in accord with the floods, etc., all are neither floods nor in accord with the floods.

As for the four kinds of practice, there is the practice of slow progress with suffering, the practice of quick progress with suffering, the practice of slow progress with joy, and the practice of quick progress with joy.
As for how many of these four kinds of practice are form, etc., all should be distinguished. That is to say, the bodily and verbal karma included in the practice is form, the rest are all formless.
As for how many are visible, etc., all are invisible.ğŸ”½As for how many are resistant, etc., all are non-resistant.
As for how many are contaminated, etc., all are uncontaminated.
As for how many are conditioned, etc., all are conditioned.
As for how many have karmic retribution, etc., all are without karmic retribution.
As for how many are born from causes, etc., all are born from causes, born from conditions, and are included in the world.

As for how many are categorized as form, etc., all should be distinguished. That is to say, the bodily and verbal karma included in the practice is categorized as form, the rest are all categorized as name.

As to how many are included in the internal sense bases, etc.: all should be discriminated. That is, the mind, thought, and consciousness included in the practice of supernormal powers are included in the internal sense bases, while the rest are included in the external sense bases.
As to how many are known by the perfect knowledge of elimination, etc.: all are known by the perfect knowledge of elimination.
As to how many are known by the perfect knowledge of elimination, etc.: all are not known by the perfect knowledge of elimination.
As to how many should be abandoned, etc.: all should not be abandoned.
As to how many should be cultivated, etc.: all should be cultivated.
As to how many are defiled, etc.: all are undefiled.
As to how many are results but not the results of anything, etc.: all are results and also the results of something.
As to how many are appropriated, etc.: all are not appropriated.

As to how many are derived from the primary elements, etc.: all should be discriminated. That is, bodily and verbal actions included in the practice of supernormal powers are derived from the primary elements, while the rest are not derived from the primary elements.
As to how many are with higher, etc.: all are with higher.
As for how many exist, none exist.

As for how many are associated with causes, etc., all should be discriminated. That is to say, the bodily and verbal actions and the factors not directly associated with the mind included in the four practices are not associated with causes, and the rest are all associated with causes.

As for the relationship between these four practices and the six wholesome bases, five wholesome bases in part include the four practices, and the four practices also include five wholesome bases in part.
As for the relationship with the five unwholesome bases, they do not mutually include each other.
As for the relationship with the seven indeterminate bases, they do not mutually include each other.
As for the relationship with the three bases of defilement, they do not mutually include each other.
As for the relationship with the five bases with defilement, they do not mutually include each other.
As for the relationship with the eight bases without defilement, five bases without defilement include the four practices, and the four practices also include five bases without defilement.
As for how many are past, etc., all are either past, future, or present.
How many are wholesome, etc.? All are wholesome.
How many are bound to the desire realm, etc.? All are unbound.
How many are learner's dharmas, etc.? All should be distinguished. The four practices are either learner's dharmas or non-learner's dharmas.
What are learner's dharmas?
They are the five aggregates of the learner.
What are non-learner's dharmas?
They are the five aggregates of the non-learner.
How many of these four practices are to be eliminated by seeing, etc.? All are not to be eliminated.

How many are not mind, etc.? All should be distinguished. That is, the bodily and verbal actions and the factors not directly associated with the mind included in the practices are not mind, not mental factors, and not directly associated with mind;
if it is the aggregate of feeling, the aggregate of perception, or the aggregate of formations associated with the mind, it is a mental factor and is directly associated with mind;
if it is mind, thought, or consciousness, it is only mind.
How many accord with the mind but are not associated with feeling, etc.? All should be distinguished. That is, each of the practices has four sentences.

Or it is associated with thought but not with feeling, namely, the bodily and verbal actions included in the practice of spiritual power, and the thought and thought concomitants and thought nonconcomitants associated with thought.
Or it is associated with feeling but not with thought, namely, the mind and thought included in the practice of spiritual power.
Or it is associated with both thought and feeling, namely, the aggregate of conception and the aggregate of the various thought concomitants included in the practice of spiritual power.

Or it is neither associated with thought nor associated with feeling, namely, the thought nonconcomitants included in the practice of spiritual power that are associated with thought, and the other thought nonconcomitants included in the practice of spiritual power.
As for how many are associated with thought but not with the aggregate of conception and the aggregate of the various thought concomitants, all should be analyzed. It is like feeling.
As for how many are associated with thought but not with applied thought and sustained thought, all should be analyzed. The practice of spiritual power that is slow and difficult has four sentences.

Or it may be associated with applied thought but not sustained thought, namely, bodily and verbal actions and formations not associated with the mind that are turned toward and included in the path of slow progress in the realization of the knowledge of the suffering of the realm of desire, and sustained thought associated with applied thought.

Or it may be associated with sustained thought but not with applied thought, namely, applied thought that is included in the path of slow progress in the realization of the knowledge of the suffering of the realm of desire, and thought and thought-concomitants associated with sustained thought but not with applied thought.

Or it may be associated with both applied and sustained thought, namely, thought and thought-concomitants associated with both applied and sustained thought and included in the path of slow progress in the realization of the knowledge of the suffering of the realm of desire.

Or it may be associated with neither applied nor sustained thought, namely, bodily and verbal actions and formations not associated with the mind, except those that are turned toward and included in the path of slow progress in the realization of the knowledge of the suffering of the realm of desire, and bodily and verbal actions and formations not associated with the mind that are included in the path of slow progress in the realization of the knowledge of the suffering of the realm of desire, and sustained thought not associated with applied thought, and thought and thought-concomitants not associated with applied thought.
The path of quick progress in the realization of the knowledge of the suffering of the realm of desire is also like this.
The path of slow progress in the realization of the knowledge of the suffering of the realm of desire also has four alternatives.

Or it may be associated with applied thought but not sustained thought, namely, the bodily and verbal actions and the dharmas unassociated with mind included in the practice of slow and blissful progress, and sustained thought.
Or it may be associated with sustained thought but not applied thought, namely, applied thought included in the practice of slow and blissful progress.

Or it may be associated with both applied and sustained thought, namely, the mind and mental activities associated with applied and sustained thought included in the practice of slow and blissful progress.

Or it may be associated with neither applied nor sustained thought, namely, the bodily and verbal actions and the dharmas unassociated with mind included in the practice of slow and blissful progress other than those associated with applied thought, and all the bodily and verbal actions and dharmas unassociated with mind included in the practice of quick and blissful progress, and the mind and mental activities devoid of applied thought and sustained thought.
The same is true of the practice of quick and blissful progress.

As for how many are views and not objects of views, etc., all must be differentiated. That is, the discernment not included in the knowledge of exhaustion and nonproduction included in the practices is view and not an object of views; the rest are neither view nor objects of views.

How many have satkÄyadrÈ™ti as their cause but are not a cause of satkÄyadrÈ™ti? All are not a cause of satkÄyadrÈ™ti but do not have satkÄyadrÈ™ti as their cause.ğŸ”½How many are karma but not karmic maturation? All should be discriminated. That is to say, the bodily and verbal karma included in the four practices is karma but not karmic maturation. The rest are neither karma nor karmic maturation.
How many are karma but not concomitant with karma? All should be discriminated. That is to say, each of the four practices has four alternatives.
Either karma but not concomitant with karma, referring to volition included in the four practices.

Either concomitant with karma but not karma, referring to the aggregates of feeling, perception, and consciousness included in the four practices, and the mental factors concomitant with karma not included in volition.
Either karma and also concomitant with karma, referring to bodily and verbal karma included in the four practices.
Either not karma and not concomitant with karma, referring to the dissociated formative forces included in the four practices, excluding the dissociated formative forces concomitant with karma.

How many are derivative form but not visible form, etc.? All should be discriminated. That is, the bodily and verbal actions included in the four practices are derivative form but not visible form. The rest are neither derivative form nor visible form.

How many are derivative form but not resistant form, etc.? All should be discriminated. That is, the bodily and verbal actions included in the four practices are derivative form but not resistant form. The rest are neither derivative form nor resistant form.
How many are difficult to see and very deep, etc.? All are difficult to see because they are very deep, and very deep because they are difficult to see.
How many are wholesome but not causes of the wholesome, etc.? All are wholesome and also causes of the wholesome.
How many are unwholesome but not causes of the unwholesome, etc.? All are neither unwholesome nor causes of the unwholesome.
How many are indeterminate but not causes of the indeterminate, etc.? All are neither indeterminate nor causes of the indeterminate.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
How many are causal conditions but not causes? All are causal conditions and also have causes.

How many are immediately preceding but not immediately preceding conditions? All should be distinguished. That is, the various practices are either immediately preceding but not immediately preceding conditions, or they are immediately preceding and also immediately preceding conditions, or they are neither immediately preceding nor immediately preceding conditions.
That which is immediately preceding but not an immediately preceding condition refers to the mind and mental factors included in the practices that are presently arising in the future.
That which is immediately preceding and also an immediately preceding condition refers to the mind and mental factors included in the practices in the past and present.

That which is neither immediately preceding nor an immediately preceding condition refers to the mind and mental factors included in the practices in the future, excluding those that are presently arising, as well as the bodily and verbal actions and factors not directly associated with the mind included in the practices.

How many are causal conditions but not causal objects? All should be discriminated. That is, the bodily and verbal actions and the factors not directly associated with mind included in the practice of the path are causal conditions but not causal objects. The rest are both causal conditions and causal objects.
How many are dominant conditions but not dominant? All are dominant conditions and also have dominance.
How many are floods but not in conformity with floods? All are neither floods nor in conformity with floods.

The four noble lineages are: the noble lineage of being content with whatever robe one obtains, the noble lineage of being content with whatever alms food one obtains, the noble lineage of being content with whatever bedding and seats one obtains, and the noble lineage of delighting in abandoning and delighting in cultivating.

How many of these four noble lineages are form, etc.? All should be discriminated. That is, the bodily and verbal actions included in the noble lineages are form. The rest are all formless.ğŸ”½How many are visible, etc.? All are invisible.
How many are resistant, etc.? All are non-resistant.
As for how many are contaminated, etc.: all should be analyzed. That is, the spiritual levels are either contaminated or uncontaminated.
How are they contaminated?
Those that are included in the contaminated five aggregates.
How are they uncontaminated?
Those that are included in the uncontaminated five aggregates.
As for how many are conditioned, etc.: all are conditioned.
As for how many have karmic retribution, etc.: all should be analyzed. That is, the spiritual levels, if contaminated, have karmic retribution; if uncontaminated, they do not have karmic retribution.
As for how many are born from causes, etc.: all are born from causes, born from conditions, and are categorized as the world.

As for how many are categorized as form, etc.: all should be analyzed. That is, the bodily and verbal actions included in the spiritual levels are categorized as form; the rest are all categorized as name.

As for how many are categorized as internal sense bases, etc.: all should be analyzed. That is, the mind, thought, and consciousness included in the spiritual levels are categorized as the internal sense bases; the rest are all categorized as the external sense bases.

How many are known by the knowledge of non-arising? All are known by the knowledge of non-arising.ğŸ”½How many are to be eliminated by the path of seeing? All are not to be eliminated by the path of seeing.ğŸ”½How many are to be eliminated by the path of cultivation? All are to be determined individually. That is, the four noble lineages, if contaminated, are to be eliminated by the path of cultivation; if uncontaminated, they are not to be eliminated.ğŸ”½How many are to be eliminated by the path of seeing? All are not to be eliminated by the path of seeing.

How many are to be eliminated by the path of cultivation? All are to be determined individually. That is, the four noble lineages, if contaminated, are to be eliminated by the path of cultivation; if uncontaminated, they are not to be eliminated.
How many are to be cultivated? All are to be cultivated.
How many are defiled? All are undefiled.
How many are results but not sources of results? All are results and also sources of results.
How many are conjoined? All are not conjoined.

How many are derived from the great elements? All are to be determined individually. That is, the bodily and verbal actions included in the four noble lineages are derived from the great elements; the rest are not derived from the great elements.
How many have superior? All have superior.
How many are existent? All should be discriminated. The four noble kinds, if impure, are existent; if pure, they are not existent.

How many are associated with causes? All should be discriminated. The bodily and verbal actions and dharmas unassociated with mind included in the four noble kinds are not associated with causes; the rest are all associated with causes.
As for the four noble kinds and the six wholesome bases, five wholesome bases partially include the four noble kinds, and the four noble kinds also partially include the five wholesome bases.
As for the five unwholesome bases, they do not mutually include each other.
As for the seven indeterminate bases, they do not mutually include each other.
As for the three bases of defilement, they do not mutually include each other.
As for the five bases with outflows, there should be four alternatives.
Either bases with outflows that are not noble kinds, namely the five aggregates with outflows not included in the noble kinds.
Or, it may be a kind of holy truth that is not a contaminated category, namely, the four holy truths that are pure.
Or, it may be a contaminated category that is also a holy truth, namely, the four holy truths that are contaminated.
Or, it may be neither a contaminated category nor a holy truth, namely, space and the two cessations.
As for the relationship between the eight pure categories and the holy truths, there are four alternatives.
Or, it may be a pure category that is not a holy truth, namely, space and the two cessations.
Or, it may be a holy truth that is not a pure category, namely, the four holy truths that are contaminated.
Or, it may be a pure category that is also a holy truth, namely, the four holy truths that are pure.
Or, it may be neither a pure category nor a holy truth, namely, the contaminated five aggregates that are not included in the holy truths.
As for whether they are past, etc., all are either past, future, or present.
As for whether they are good, etc., all are good.

How many are bound to the desire realm, etc.? All should be discriminated. That is, the noble lineages are either bound to the desire realm, or bound to the form realm, or bound to the formless realm, or unbound.
How are they bound to the desire realm?
It refers to the five aggregates of the desire realm included in the noble lineages.
How are they bound to the form realm?
It refers to the five aggregates of the form realm included in the noble lineages.
How are they bound to the formless realm?
It refers to the four aggregates of the formless realm included in the noble lineages.
How are they unbound?
It refers to the five aggregates that are pure.
How many are learners, etc.? All should be discriminated. That is, the noble lineages are either learners, or post-learners, or neither learners nor post-learners.
What are learners?
It refers to the five aggregates of learners.
What are post-learners?
It refers to the five aggregates of post-learners.
What are neither learners nor post-learners?
It refers to the five aggregates with impurities included in the noble lineages.

As for how many of these four noble lineages are to be eliminated by seeing and so on, all should be distinguished. That is to say, the noble lineages, if contaminated, are to be eliminated by cultivation; if uncontaminated, they are not to be eliminated.

As for how many are not mind and so on, all should be distinguished. That is to say, the bodily and verbal actions and factors not directly associated with thought included in the noble lineages are not mind, are not mental activities, and are not directly associated with mind.
The aggregate of sensation, the aggregate of conception, and the aggregate of karmic formations associated with the noble lineages are mental activities and are directly associated with mind.
The mind, thought, and consciousness included in the noble lineages are only mind.

As for how many accord with the mind but are not associated with sensation, all should be distinguished. That is to say, each of the noble lineages has four alternatives.ğŸ”½Either they accord with the mind but are not associated with sensation, referring to bodily and verbal actions and factors not directly associated with thought that accord with the mind and are included in the noble lineages, as well as sensation.
Or they are associated with sensation but do not accord with the mind, referring to the mind, thought, and consciousness included in the noble lineages.

Or, they are both concomitant with thought and associated with feeling, namely, the aggregate of conceptualization and the aggregate of compositional factors associated with it that are included in the category of the requisites of enlightenment.

Or, they are neither concomitant with thought nor associated with feeling, namely, those that are included in the category of the requisites of enlightenment and are bodily and verbal actions and the formations that are not associated with thought.

How many are concomitant with thought but are not associated with conceptualization and ideation? All should be investigated. With the exception of their own natures, they should be understood in the same way as feeling.

How many are concomitant with thought and with investigation but are not associated with analysis? All should be investigated. Each of the categories of the requisites of enlightenment has four alternatives.ğŸ”½Or, they are concomitant with thought and with investigation but are not associated with analysis, namely, bodily and verbal actions and the formations that are not associated with thought and are concomitant with investigation that are included in the category of the requisites of enlightenment, and investigation that is associated with analysis.

Or, they are associated with analysis but are not concomitant with thought and with investigation, namely, investigation that is included in the category of the requisites of enlightenment and is not associated with thought, and thought and thought-concomitants that are associated with analysis and are not investigation.

Or, they are associated with applied thought and also with sustained thought, namely, the mind and mental activities associated with applied thought and sustained thought included in the four noble truths.

Or, they are neither associated with applied thought nor associated with sustained thought, namely, the bodily and verbal actions and dharmas unassociated with mind included in the four noble truths that are not associated with applied thought, sustained thought, and sustained thought not associated with applied thought, and the mind and mental activities that are neither associated with applied thought nor with sustained thought.
As for whether they are views or objects of views, etc., each of the four noble truths must be analyzed into four sentences.
Or, they are views but not objects of views, namely, pure discernment not included in the knowledge of elimination and knowledge of non-production.
Or, they are objects of views but not views, namely, the impure four noble truths not included in views.
Or, they are both views and objects of views, namely, mundane right views included in the four noble truths.
Or, they are neither views nor objects of views, namely, the pure four noble truths not included in views.
How many have satkÄyadrÈ™ti as their cause but are not a cause of satkÄyadrÈ™ti? All are not a cause of satkÄyadrÈ™ti but have satkÄyadrÈ™ti as their cause.

How many are karma but not karmic maturation? All should be discriminated. That is, the bodily and verbal karma included in the bases are karma but not karmic maturation, the rest are neither karma nor karmic maturation.

How many are karma but not concomitant with karma? All should be discriminated. That is, each of the bases has four alternatives.ğŸ”½Either karma but not concomitant with karma, referring to bodily and verbal karma included in the bases that are not concomitant with karma, and volition.

Either concomitant with karma but not karma, referring to the aggregates of feeling, perception, and consciousness included in the bases, and the aggregate of formations not included in volition that is concomitant with karma.
Either karma and also concomitant with karma, referring to bodily and verbal karma included in the bases that is concomitant with karma.
Or neither karma nor that which is concomitant with karma, namely, the formations dissociated from thought included in the noble practices, excluding those that are concomitant with karma.

As for how many are derivative form but not visible form, etc., all should be discriminated. That is, bodily and verbal actions included in the noble practices are derivative form but not visible form. The rest are neither derivative form nor visible form.

As for how many are derivative form but not resistant, etc., all should be discriminated. That is, bodily and verbal actions included in the noble practices are derivative form but not resistant. The rest are neither derivative form nor resistant.

As for how many are difficult to see because they are profound, etc., all are difficult to see because they are profound, and profound because they are difficult to see.ğŸ”½As for how many are wholesome but not causes of the wholesome, etc., all are wholesome and also causes of the wholesome.
As for how many are unwholesome but not causes of the unwholesome, etc., all are neither unwholesome nor causes of the unwholesome.
How many are indeterminate and not causes of indeterminate dharmas? All are not indeterminate and not causes of indeterminate dharmas.
How many are causal conditions but not causes? All are causal conditions and also have causes.

How many are immediately antecedent but not immediately antecedent conditions? All should be distinguished. That is, the noble lineages may be immediately antecedent but not immediately antecedent conditions, may be immediately antecedent and also immediately antecedent conditions, or may neither be immediately antecedent nor immediately antecedent conditions.ğŸ”½That which is immediately antecedent but not an immediately antecedent condition refers to the mind and mental factors included in the noble lineages that are presently arising in the future.
That which is immediately antecedent and also an immediately antecedent condition refers to the mind and mental factors included in the noble lineages in the past and present.

As for those that are neither similar and immediately antecedent conditions nor similar and immediately antecedent conditions, it means all future holy seeds that are not presently arising mind and mental factors, as well as the holy seeds that are bodily and verbal actions and the factors not directly associated with mind.

As for how many are objects of cognition but not objects of cognition, all should be distinguished. That is to say, the bodily and verbal actions and factors not directly associated with mind included in the holy seeds are objects of cognition but not objects of cognition, while the rest are both objects of cognition and objects of cognition.
As for how many are dominant conditions but not have dominance, all are dominant conditions and also have dominance.

As for how many are floods but not in accord with floods, all should be distinguished. That is to say, the holy seeds that are contaminated are in accord with floods but not floods, while those that are uncontaminated are neither floods nor in accord with floods.
Just as with the four holy seeds, the four right efforts and the four bases of supernatural power are also like this.

The four establishments of mindfulness are the establishment of mindfulness of the body, the establishment of mindfulness of feelings, the establishment of mindfulness of mind, and the establishment of mindfulness of dharmas.
What is the establishment of mindfulness of the body?
It is good, contaminated and uncontaminated wisdom that takes the body as its object.
What is the establishment of mindfulness of feelings?
It is good, contaminated and uncontaminated wisdom that takes feelings as its object.
What is the establishment of mindfulness of mind?
It is good, contaminated and uncontaminated wisdom that takes mind as its object.
What is the establishment of mindfulness of dharmas?
It is good, contaminated and uncontaminated wisdom that takes dharmas as its object.
As for whether these four establishments of mindfulness are form, etc., all are formless.
As for whether they are visible, etc., all are invisible.
As for whether they are obstructive, etc., all are non-obstructive.
As for whether they are contaminated, etc., all should be distinguished. The wisdom that takes the body as its object is either contaminated or uncontaminated.
How is it contaminated?
It is the wisdom that takes the body as its object and is associated with contaminated attention.
How is it uncontaminated?
It is the wisdom that takes the body as its object and is associated with uncontaminated attention.
The wisdom that takes feeling, mind, and dharmas as its object is also like this.
As for how many are conditioned, etc., all are conditioned.

As for how many have karmic retribution, etc., all should be distinguished. The four establishments of mindfulness, if contaminated, have karmic retribution; if uncontaminated, they have no karmic retribution.
As for how many are born from causes and conditions, etc., all are born from causes and conditions, born from causes, and are included in the world.
As for how many are categorized as form, etc., all are categorized as name.
As for how many are categorized as internal sense bases, etc., all are categorized as external sense bases.
As for how many are known by the perfect knowledge of elimination, etc., all are known by the perfect knowledge of elimination.Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Compendium of the MahÄyÄna Abhidharma, Fascicle 11
